title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.14.34 | 16-11-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Being illusioned by false pleasures of the senses one becomes a servant of the senses.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts material and transcendental pleasure, explaining that attachment to sense gratification makes one a servant of the senses, and emphasizes the need for Krishna's protection.

segments.key_quote: Prosperity in our human society depends on two things cow protection cow should never be killed.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the importance of cow protection and brahminical culture for societal prosperity, stating that those who neglect these principles are not under Krishna's direct protection, using the analogy of prisoners in jail.

segments.key_quote: One can become a brahmana and thus see the lord as he is if we become anybody can become a qualified brahmana simply by following the brahmanical principles and awaken the good qualities within by practicing brahmanical culture and then one can see the lord as he is.
segments.summary: The speaker continues on the usefulness of the cow, even after death, and then describes the qualities of a brahmana and how developing these qualities allows one to see the Lord.

segments.key_quote: After surpassing the brahmanical perfection one has to become a devotee of the lord.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that after achieving brahminical perfection, one must become a devotee to develop a loving relationship with Krishna as proprietor, master, friend, son, or lover.

segments.key_quote: To come to the transcendental state one has to first of all elevate oneself to the platform of goodness above rajoguna and tamoguna.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of rising to the platform of goodness (brahminical qualities) to transcend the modes of passion and ignorance and become a qualified devotee, clarifying that claiming to be a brahmana by birth is insufficient without the qualities.

segments.key_quote: Those who are less than a brahmana by qualification cannot establish any relation with the lord just as fire cannot be kindled from the raw earth unless there is wood.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of fire, wood, and earth to illustrate that a relationship with the Lord cannot be established without proper qualification, and concludes by stating that Maharaj Yudhishthir did not inquire about Krishna's welfare because Krishna is eternally perfect.
